text:
I would give this 10 stars if I could!!  I used a deep cast iron skillet instead of my deep fryer simply because it was quicker.  We had our 2 sons and son-in-law here today for football.  With 4 grown men, I decided to quadruple everything.  THAT was not smart because I needed at least 20 more wings!  They loved them and so did my daughter and I.  I took another reviewer's advice and after frying, paper-toweling, tossing in a tupperware lidded bowl with the hot sauce, I put them on a pan and into the oven at 350 for about 8 minutes.  Buffalo wings that are not super-messy!  It's a dream come true!!  Thanks for such a fantastic recipe.  We will have these every weekend between now and the Super Bowl, at my husand and children's request.

text:
Everyone Loved this chicken. Very crispy and good. I made it as stated except I did not have cayenne pepper so I used chili powder, also I added a bit of sugar to the sauce and I used less hot sauce becasue My kids cant do spicy. I was concerned at first because the sauce was not at all creamy or well blended. The hot sauce made a paste at the bottom of a LOT of butter but, when cooled a bit it tasted good so I put it on and It was fine. The butter didn't make the chicken soggy, it was still crisp and good. I will defiantly do this again and My husband will be making sure of that. Thank you for this great addition to our family's meal.

userID:
3210017
Display Name:
mrssabre
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/658703.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for my wing loving fiance, and he loved them! He likes his wings on the BBQ, so of course I had to make them on the BBQ. I was trying to figure out a way to make this deep fry recipe work on the BBQ while still having that same crisp I've read about from other reviews. So what I did was made the hot sauce part, let the wings sit in the hot sauce for an hour, then I mixed up the dry ingredients(double the amount suggested) put half on the bottom of a glass bowl and half on top of the wings, and let them sit in the fridge for a little over an hour. I got the BBQ going, and then put them on. I made the mistake of turning them too soon and some of the breading came off, and some got stuck to the BBQ during flipping them. LET THEM GET CRISPY ON BOTH SIDES BEFORE FLIPPING. I made another batch of hot sauce so I could rub it on them during cooking, which turned out good. He loved them and they were hot enough for him, and I will be making these again(I won't spend the money at a restaurant again) but I will let them crisp before rubbing on the hot sauce.

im making these tonight, AGAIN! dont skimp on leaving them in the fridge the entire time..its the key to a crispy outer shell. i like my wings HOT and the sauce recipe falls short of what i like. i use franks extra hot sauce and add a drop or two of daves insanity sauce. i've tried perfecting my wings for many years but never quite got the results i was looking for until i tried it this way. you cant go wrong with this recipe. this is even better than marinating your wings in buttermilk imo. 5 stars.

text:
These were great. We skipped the refrigeration step and baked ours on a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper.  We baked at 375 for 20 minutes (because we had some artichoke dip in the oven at the same time), than cranked up the heat to 450 and baked for another 30 minutes, turning them about half way through.  No need to add any spray oild because the grease that the chicken releases itself is enough to crisp them up a bit.  We used 2/3 butter, 1/3 cup Frank's sauce as suggested by another review and they were great!  Will make these again.

text:
These were EXCELLENT! I decided to bake half and fry half. The ones we fried were MUCH better. If you do bake them, make sure you grease your pan a lot. I baked them on a cookie sheet for 45 minutes, flipping once and the skin stuck to the sheet like crazy! I used Ken's hot sauce marinade and butter on the baked batch, and butter and Franks on the other (fried batch) The sauce was perfect, add more or less depending on what you like. I will definitely be using this again and again. Just in time for football too!!

text:
These were terrific! I tripled the recipe (for 30 wings, approx 4lb bag frozen) for a community  picnic in the park. They were an absolute hit! EVERYONE loved them, from the smallest kid to the oldest gramma! They were gone quicker than I expected!   They weren't too hot (which I liked). However, others do prefer a spicier wing so I may try to do some variations next time with the seasonings on half of them to give them some heat.  The other "problem/issue" I had was, once they were all done frying and coated (I did them in batches due to the size of my pan) the few first ones became a little soggy, I'm not sure why, but I may try to put them on a rack in the oven while the rest cook just so they aren't sitting with the liquid hot sauce cooling for so long.  Great Great recipe! I can't wait to make them again... and I'm not a big wing fan!! ...well until now!!

text:
I have made these a few times now and everyone LOVES these. I tried as written and I have tried it with the breading then eggs wash and breading again. I like it the best with breading it twice (no egg wash) I bread it once put in the fridge for about 3-4 hours and bread again and the re fridge for another 3-4 hours. These are just 100% awesome. I tried the sauce today with 1/3 butter and 2/3 Franks buffalo hot wing sauce. It's all good. When I am making these for a crowd, I deep fry them the day before for 6-7 minutes @ 375. The next day I put them in the oven @ 375 for 10-12 minutes. Thanks for the recipe.

*Fat~Dog~Lane*

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used thighs & drumsticks but cut the thighs into two sections, leaving a bone in each piece.  I loved how meaty they were this way!  The sauce had amazing flavor and the chicken was perfectly crispy & juicy with a 90min rest.  I used 3/4's cup butter because I'm a whimp with the spice. I just fried it like reg. fried chicken in a hot pan, 1/4" to 1/2" of oil.  This uses way less oil than a deep fryer and gets a nice crisp on the chicken.  Thanks for the recipe, it's requested often in our house!  **Here's an easy, mild bleu cheese dressing** 1/2 c. mayo, 1/2 c. sour cream, 2 green onions sliced, 2-3 tbsp fresh lemon juice, fresh ground black pepper, 1/4 c. bleu cheese crumbled.  **UPDATE** I always soak the raw chicken pieces in buttermilk ( or milk plus vinegar to sour) plus a little salt and hot sauce in the milk.  Adds another layer of moist, tasty wonderfulness!

None
text:
These were good but I had one problem.  When I cooked them I sprayed the Pam on them, like suggested, and my oven started to smoke like it was on fire!  So, if you decide to bake them completely REMOVE them from the oven, spray, then put back in.  The only other suggestion I have is shaking off the excess flour with a strainer before you put them in the oven.  This helps with even baking.  If not you'll end up with flour still on some wings.

text:
Holy cow if there is such a thing.  I love trying new recipes but this buffalo chicken wing recipe is the absolute BEST!  I was absolutely amazed that the process of dipping it in the flour mixture and then refrigerating for 2 hours produced a super battered chicken wing, nice and crispy.  I finally know now that that's probably how they also make orange chicken... Same process, dipping in flour mixture, refrigerating and then deep frying, topping the finished product with the orange sauce.  I'll try the orange chicken next time and I'm sure it'll be a winner also.  I'm not kidding, you guys have got to try this recipe.  I doubled the recipe and did 22 fresh chicken wings and they were all gone on Superbowl Sunday.  A definite keeper!

text:
A quick tip for a GREAT sauce if you don't have all the ingredients. Soften  butter (to room temp) and mix about half butter with half "Louisiana" hot sauce (Louisiana works the absolute best) in a bowl. Stir butter and hot sauce together and toss onto hot wings. It's great, cheap, and tastes just like most buffalo sauces out there. A very close version of Hooters' sauce.

text:
I have followed the directions exactly when I made this recipe before, and let them sit in the frig for and hour or longer. They came out perfect!  But, tonight I really wanted to make this recipe at the last minute, but didn't have time to let them sit in the frig, so I coated them as directed, and then deep fried them just after I floured them.  They still came out awesome! If time allows, always try to let sit in the frig for the recommended time, but if you are in a hurry, they are still worth making without letting them sit in the frig.  By the way, I did this batch with chicken cutlets and came out just as good as the "wings" I have made in the past.  
Thanks for sharing this recipe!

WOW!  I use the bagged, frozen wings (thawed & drained well).  The flour will coat up to 15-20 wings, actually.  These bake up well using Reynolds Non-stick foil and baking according to the bag (mine says 375' for 35-45 min).  Since I bake mine, I slather some sauce on part of the way through; flip the wings, then add remainder of sauce.  These get RAVE reviews from DIE-HARD WING LOVERS!

Made these last week and had to go get more wings.  My husband and kids raved about them. Don't skip chilling the wings once they're dusted.  Makes the difference absolutely! Deep fried they came out crispy and I used a bottled sauce I had bought at the grocery store. I think it was called Anchor Bar, very spicy and good. OMG!!!  These were awesome!  As so many users suggested, I used the Frank's brand hot sauce. I purchased the XTRA HOT version, as we love our spices! This will also help the wings to soak up the sauce....MMMMMMMMMM GOOD!!! Thanks for the recipe!!

I've never made Buffalo Chicken before. My boyfriend only likes breast meat, so I used chicken breast rather than wings. I used Tabasco sauce, and really liked it. To make the fried chicken though, I did it the way I usually do fried chicken- coat with seasoned flour, then egg-milk mixture, and then back in the flour miwture again. I liked it better that way. I will be making this recipe again. ***I just wanted to update my review. I love the tabasco sauce flavor but it is so hot!! So I decideed to use half bbq sauce and half tabasco sauce. My boyfriend loved it and wanted more the next day, but I realized I had used up all the bbq sauce. So I mixed ketsup and brown sugar and a squirt of mustard. I combined it with the butter nd some garlic powder. I am telling you IT WAS THE BEST CHICKEN I EVER MADE!!! I wil make it this way from now on! And my boyfriend could not get enough! ;)

text:
Much better tasting than Hooter's wings and not as greasy. I tried them both fried & baked and husband and I both liked the fried ones better.  We really liked the sauce (Used Frank's after all the great reviews) and compared it to Hooter's Mild wings.  The breading was very light but crispy (They even were crispy the next day as leftovers!). I mixed the flour mixture in a large plastic bag and added the chicken wings and shook it up to coat them completely.  To make the sauce I just melted the butter in the microwave and added the hot sauce & seasonings.  Just heated it up again in the microwave before serving.  We are already planning to make up 6 dozen for our next football party!

text:
Excellent hot wing recipe!!  The combination of flour and the resting time in the refrigerator makes these wings super crispy when you fry them. Yum!

The sauce can be made at any time - the original Franks hot sauce has just enough spicy to make the wings tasty, but not so spicy that you will sweat.

The basic flouring recipe/technique is a winner and one I'll use to cook up our other favorite wing recipe with an Asian style sauce.

Thank you for the great easy wing recipe!  My husband is still raving about them :D

text:
I've made this two times. The first time I made them boneless and baked them. I thought they tasted a lot like chicken tenders vs. boneless buffalo wings. This time I made regular wings and deep fried them. They were better. I had problems though with the breading falling off during the process. I think they are really good although I've had other kinds that I think are better. I don't recommned putting the wings into a ziplock during the flouring- I think it coats better if you do it in the glass dish as recommended. I will make these again.

userID:

Display Name:
BRIANMAN

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only change I make is to fry them a little longer to make them more crispy. I like to fry them for about 20 minutes. 

For big football parties I will fry up 5 dozen wings the night before and refrigerate without sauce. Then on game day I just sauce them up and throw them on a grill to heat up. This also sears the sauce into the wing a little which adds more flavor.

text:
Never having made buffalo wings before, I made sure to read all the reviews before I set out on this new adventure.  I followed a lot of the advice given:  I used chicken breasts cut into strips the size of wings, made sure to coat the strips AND marinate for 90 min, doubled the sauce, and fried the "wings" in olive oil (just enough to coat the bottom of the pan).  The result was GREAT!  My husband asked for a little more spice next time, but the "wings'" apparent mildness didn't stop him from all but licking his plate clean.  Next time I will add more cayenne to the flour mixture and perhaps experiment with a hotter hot sauce.  I can't wait to take these to parties!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is wonderful.  I like my chicken seasoned all the way through.  So I seasoned my chicken like normal using unseasoned meat tenderizer, accent, seasoning salt and black pepper.  I let it sit for 45 min. Then I added the flour mixture without the salt.  Then I placed it in the refridgerator for 60 min.  I was afraid to use cayenne pepper...I used crushed red pepper instead in the flour mixture.  I also used white pepper in the sauce.  I made a double of the sauce because I used boneless skinless thighs instead of wings.  Awesome.  I will use less butter the next time and use cayenne pepper to make it spicer.  But it was perfect for the kids using crushed red pepper.  Not too spicy using crushed red pepper.  My husband just loved it.  They are ready for the next time.  This is a keeper. This is the third recipe I have used and this is the only one that came out perfect.   Thank you!

I LOVED this. Anyone who wants to be a wing snob, just sit down. These were delicious and crispy. My only changes were 1/2 cup of flour & 1/2 cup of corn starch with seasonings for the flour mix. Deep fried for 15 minutes, and they were crispy even when sauced. I made my own sauce since more people in my house like a BBQ sauce. The secret really is the chilling in the fridge and letting the flour and the chicken become friends. Basically the secret I've discovered in all chicken frying.

text:
I did 50+ wings tonight so I did the recipe x5.  Next time I would only use 1/4 cup of butter for the same amount of wings because we found them way to rich.  I also added 2 tablespoons of pepper because we love pepper.  We also omitted the flour because we avoid adding fat to more fat.  All the spices were excellent!  I just added all of them after frying the wings in Extra Virgin Olive Oil.  Definitely a must try.  I'd give this recipe a 5 out of 5 with my changes though.

text:
I made these for my brother, a very picky eater, and he (and I) loved them! One step I added was to kind of marinate the chicken in some ranch seasoning mix, red pepper flakes, and hot sauce...just enough to coat the wings a bit. I let the marinade sit on the wings for a full day in the refrigerator or freezer before coating the wings at all. Then, I prepared as normal. This gave the chicken itself amazing flavor throughout, just the right amount of kick once you get past the spicy breading.

text:
Won't make again.  I deep fried them nice and crispy but the coating was bland and the wings didn't shrink much, they were bulky and not juicy.  I will stick to my usual method which is to bake the wings from frozen for about 1 hour.  They are much more tender, flavorful, and crispy this way without adding any flour.  I usually use Franks and butter for sauce but it is a bit on the greasy side.  The only bottled sauce I tried that I like is Heritage Farms so I'll use that if I don't want all that butter.

text:
Just made this recipe tonight for my family of seven (50 wings - so I had to adjust the recipe accordingly), they were the BEST!!! The only changes I made was to add 3 crushed cloves of garlic to the pan with a couple Tablespoons of butter to saute it before adding the remaining butter and Frank's Red Hot. Also, due to making so many and only being able to fry small batches at a time in my fryer, I baked them in the oven at 375 for 30 minutes, then I fried each batch for only 5 minutes. They came out absolutely perfect!!! Thank you!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-06-10T07:28:34.51
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
7527925
Display Name:
Erica L Ingram
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
28
favoritesCount:
153
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/849937.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made these pretty much at least once a week every week since i found this recipe a year or whatever ago.  I give out this recipe and share it every chance I get.  I have probably 50 pictures of these wings on my facebook page.  

However, I sub out the two pepper spices listed for habanero and red savinas.  I have made this recipe so many times i usually just eyeball the ingredients until the batter color is right because we like our wings very spicy.  We have tried this batter recipe (various sauces) with paprika, crushed red pepper, cayenne, habanero, and red savinas.

We have gotten to where we prefer the batter to be spicier and then put on much less sauce and the wings are on the drier side, so we put a little more ground habanero and red savinas in than we used to and then we omit some hot sauce and butter.  

Frank's hot sauce is pretty mild, so we don't use it.  We have made these with all the red Tabasco sauces, Frank's red and wing, Grace's, Louisiana, three different kinds of Barbecue sauce, garlic butter, Cholula's, Tapatio, and another specialty kind from a local market here in the area.  These are very versatile wings and can be made to suit anybody.  

For frying, we thaw the wings, batter, let them sit in fridge for 90 minutes, preheat fryer 60 minutes through the 90 minutes, and cook them at 375 for 20 to 30 minutes, pretty straightforward.  I have uploaded probably seven to ten pictures of my wings in various forms.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-05-21T09:25:12.11

text:
Tried them baked and fried - DEFINITELY worth the effort to deep-fry them.  MUCH better that way. This is my third weekend in a row to make them - and my kids are starting to bring their friends home for them!  I don;t have a deep fryer, so I used the candy thermometer in a regular pot method.  Make sure you have a REALLY nice thermometer.  And watch out!  The temperature really dips between batches. I may have to bite the bullet and invest in a deep fryer. We put them out and then have bowls of different sauces for all the different palates.  I prefer THIS sauce, although I decrease the butter by half to up the intensity.

text:
Great recipe - I was unable to find "drummettes" in the store, so I used the frozen Party Style Wings.  Although small, they were big on taste.  As per another reviewers comments, if you like hotter wings, lower the amount of butter and increase the amount of hot sauce.  I used 1/3 butter and 2/3 sauce and it was still not hot enough some!  I fried them in a bit of oil until just brown and then baked at 350 for 20 min, basting each time I turned them, which was once or twice.  Definetly try this recipe for great wings done at home!

text:
This recipes is fantastic! If you like your wings a little milder (as my boyfriend does), omit the cayenne pepper and add a little extra butter and some cola to the sauce. It will help tone down the spice a bit without effecting the flavor. As far as measurements go - when I'm toning down the sauce a bit I usually add about 1/8 of a cup extra butter and I don't measure the cola, I would say approximately 1/8 of a cup. It's best to do it by taste.

I followed the recipe exactly, except I baked them for about 50 minutes. I coated the pan with pam, put the floured wings on that pan, refridgerated them for 90 min.  Baked at 375 for 15 min, then 350 for 20 min. Coated wings w Pam (both sides), flipped them over, and baked at 400 for about 15 min. They were delicious and crispy. Will be making these again. YUM

text:
This is an amazing recipe and it tastes just like I got them at a restaurant. I didn't have any Chicken Wings, so I instead used Chicken Breast cut into thin strips and chunks. They turned out absolutely delicious. I followed the recipe almost exactly, only changing one thing. I double battered the Chicken by first battering them, putting them in another bowl and wetting with some water(Milk would work excellent as well). Then just stick them back in the batter and you'll have some nice, thick battered Chicken. Just like the restaurants make.

text:
These are TRULY fantastic! They don't have to be so complicated, though, or take so long.   I dip them in flour with cajun seasoning and let them sit while I'm frying the previous batch for about 12 minutes.  When they come out, we dip them in a mixture of half melted butter and half Frank's Red Hot. They're truly incredible!  I don't know anyone who would drink Zinfandel with them, either. (See the drink recommendation.) They should be served with your favorite cold beer.

text:
I often leave mine in the fridge for longer than called for depending on whats going on.  I asked in Hooters one day, and they said they flour theirs in the morning and based on demand they may stay in there till the afternoon. I have found that cooking time is a lot shorter with the wings available to me, usually takes around ten minutes. I also skipped the watery hot sauce for Batch #218 Louisiana Style Hot Sauce by Original Juan, but dont put in as much as they have excellent taste and enough heat to spare. If you need hotter they will have it, and the flavor is awesome.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the most requested dish I make from my family - which includes two teenaged boys - and their friends. I make them as directed. A few hints: Refrigerating the battered wings is crucial. Don't pack them too tight. I batter each wing separately, it doesn't take much longer and makes such you get a good coating. Fry the full 15 minutes - it makes a difference. Be sure to turn if you're frying in a pan that doesn't completely cover the wings. Don't overcrowd the wings in the fryer. I use Frank's hot sauce - it's awesome - and I use equal parts sauce and butter. Some reviewer recommend baking. Yes, that would be healthier, but sometimes you just have to live a little.

text:
This was the BEST! Finally I've found a way to satisfy my wing craving without looking for babysitters for a trip to the local pub. YUM! We tried these both deep fried and baked, and both were delicious. I actually think I preferred the baked though! The skin was crunchier, which to me is a bonus!  --[tip to those without a deep fryer- I put a glass casserole dish in the oven, half full with oil and heated to 375. I then put the wings in to fry. Be cautious when opening the oven- I originally put in too much oil and it started to burn on the bottom when spilled, causing my eyes to water. Open door with face turned away!].-- I also used the leftover wing sauce as dipping sauce- I just added more Franks to spice it up a bit more and DELICIOUS!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The sauce was great! We used a deep fryer for the first time to cook the chicken wings, which we got frozen at the store. Apparently that batch of chicken was on steroids because they were the largest wings we have seen! Needless to say they took more room up in the deep fryer, so we had to cook them in batches. We combined them in a bowl with the sauce as they came out hot and fresh. Unfortunately, this caused the coating to get a little soggy. We kept the leftovers and the next day at a family dinner, we made another batch of sauce and broiled them in the oven for about 10 minutes. This crisped them up just fine and they were delicious! We also added a little cayenne pepper to the sauce on the 2nd day to give it a little extra kick! Great recipe!

text:
Absolutely Delicious!  I sprayed the wings with cooking spray, then baked on a rack(so the oil drains) over a cookie sheet @ 350 for 35 minutes, then turned the heat to 400 degrees for 10 minutes to crisp them up.  We like it hot so I just tossed it with extra cayenne pepper, Franks Red Hot and enjoyed; I even used crushed Pork Rinds instead of the flour mixture to make this low carb.  PERFECT and satisfying!  Thanks for the baking suggestion!

text:
i use similar recipe but add 1/4 pint of vinegar to butter and hot sauce and then reduce and thicken with cornflour.the real secret to crispness is to put wings on a rack in fridge overnight, this draws all moisture from skin and is what they do in most restaurants.

text:
This is a recipe I have made forever! The only thing I change is that I use self-rising flour! It really gives it a little extra crunch. Definately don't skip on the refrigeration!! I also change up the sauce ratio depending on how HOT our guests like them. Also, tasting the sauce it may seem hot but it will lose some of it's spice when tossed with the wings. FYI- this is actually a Hooter's wing recipe :)

There really isn't anything that I can say that hasn't been said already.  This is a spot-on recipe.  Not one single change needed!  I made a quadruple batch of the recipe and cooked them in 2 batches in the Turkey fryer.  After the first batch was done, I spread them on a cookie sheet and put then in the oven at 200 degrees to keep warm until the second batch was done.  I used Frank's Red Hot sauce with the seasonings and butter.  OMG...they were amazing!!  This will become a go-to party recipe in my house!

userID:

Display Name:
Elizabeth Aulwes

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1252447.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for a super bowl party and they were a huge hit. I used the raw pre-cut chicken tenders and coated them with the flour mixture the day before. I also made the hot sauce-butter the day before and reheated it in the microwave before coating the fried chicken. That worked fine, but the mix did seperate a bit and required lengthy re-stirring. In retrospect, it probably would have been easier to make that portion while frying the chicken. Also, I'm not sure how hot the oil in my fryer was (it was borrowed so I'd never used it before) but the first batch, which I cooked for 10 minutes before checking, were overcooked. I shortened the subsequent batches to only five minutes and that was much better. I've also made this quick and simple (though not healthy) sauce several times since that party and it's always been delicious, even on a buffalo chicken pizza once.

text:
Perfect recipe! I tripled the recipe and fried them in three batches.  I don't have a deep fryer so I just fried them on the stove and used a candy/oil thermometer to check the temp.  I also covered half of them in the hot sauce (using Texas Pete) as directed, and the other half in barbecue sauce for my kids. To make the barbecue sauce I just substituted bottled sauce for the hot sauce in the butter mixture. I agree with other reviewers that the key is to refrigerate the wings for the full time to get a good coating. I will be making these again and again!

text:
I made it the way the recipe says (really great!) and then I made it a different way too.  I pulled the skin off the wings and sprinkled cayenne pepper and pam over the wings.  Then I baked them until they were done (it took a while, maybe 45 minutes at 350?).  Then I brushed on the sauce.  My husband prefers the baked method.  Either way great recipe!

text:
I couldn't believe how great these came out.  I took a chance I did the baked version first and I promise you, if you love wings but don't love the calories go for this version.  You will not be disappointed. Just make sure you wait the 90 minutes (at least) in the fridge.  I baked mine in my small B&D convection oven using the rectangular pan & insertable grill rack so the fat from the skin would drip off of them even.  I only baked them for 35 minutes on 400 degrees (flipping once in between)using the CONVECTION setting so they would be evenly browned.  I took the advice of another reveiwer and used less butter in the sauce, making it spicier & less fattening.  I'm in heaven now :)

text:
These wings are nothing short of fantastic!  After finding this recipe just 2 weeks ago, we've made them several times now - my husband and I are addicted!  The key is allowing them to sit in the refrigerator, however, this last time I left them in there for about 1/2hr instead of longer and they still came out perfect.  After deep frying I put them into a plastic container with the wing sauce, put the lid on and gently shook it until the wings were coated - this is such an easy method and helps to coat all the wings evenly.  I have made these wings using Lousiania hot sauce as well as a honey-garlic version... all I can say is yum... yum...  will definitely make again and again... thanks for the recipe!!

userID:
2861826
Display Name:
sailshonan
isPro:
False
followersCount:
60
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
260
favoritesCount:
702
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/184809.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
While living in Japan, the American food I miss the most is wings.  You'll find me at TGIFridays Yokohama every few weeks just to have wings.  I have made this in Japan and in the US many times and it's been a long learning process to get it right. I carefully coat each one,lay them out in a glass dish layer by by layer, and sprinkle flour between each layer.  This will require about 50% more coating mix than the recipe lists.  It's very important that each wing is fully and not haphazardly coated.  When loading into the fry basket, I also stir the wing arond in the coating just to ensure full coverage.  After leaving them in the fridge for at least 3 hours, the method of preparation is key.  I have made them in a cast iron pan, in a small deep fryer and in a turkey fryer.  Getting the oil hot enough to cook the wings in about 10 min. time is critical.  Otherwise, they'll absorb too much oil and the coating become too greasy/soggy.  It's difficult for me to control the temp in a cast iron pan, so if I use a small deep fryer, I do them a few at a time so as not to lower the oil temperature too much and cause too much oil absorption by the wings.  The turkey fryer stays hot and I can fry many at a time and yields picture perfect wings!!  I use Frank's Buffalo Wing sauce, but if preparing your own from this recipe, I prefer to add about 1/4 as much red wine vinegar as butter.  If you like Hooter's sauce, then you'll want the vinegar.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
These were excellent, but I did make some changes just for the sake of saving time. I coated the wings in the flour and only let them sit for 20 minutes because of a time crunch, then I deep fried them for only 5 minutes, then I stuck them onto a cookie sheet and baked them because I prefer my wings baked. I baked them at 375 for about 40 minutes until they were done, coated them in sauce, and the turned the broiler on and stuck them in for about 5 minutes to give them added crunch. They were excellent and next time I will try sticking more closely to the recipe, but I will definitely make again!

text:
Really good chicken wings.  I made these the other night and the only change I made was to increase the butter and hot sauce to 1/3 cup because I made more than 10 wings (about 24 split chicken wings).  I also added about 2 Tbsp of honey to the sauce to give it a bit of sweetness; this was great because it cut through the heat really well.  I also did not add the cayenne pepper to the flour mixture and added seasoning salt instead.  I will definitely make these chicken wings again!

text:
I made this for my family and they loved it!! Personally,  I think it's great. The type of hot sauce used is quite important. The hot sauce i used had a different taste, causing that odd taste to emerge in the wings. The next time i'll use conventional tobasco sauce and see what happens. Also, try doing the sauce just before you serve. If you make it to early, the sauce thickens a bit and mixing it with the wings could be difficult. Overall, excellent recipe! Thanx!

text:
Love these!!! I made these to enjoy with the Superbowl game and they were soooo good!!  I was surprised how easy they really were.  I used the chicken drummettes (instead of wings) and added a little more butter to the sauce and they were delicious, but next time I'll spice it up a little more (my husband prefers them on the hotter side!)  The only other thing I did add was I sprinkled the wings with "Chicken Seasoning" to add alittle more flavor to the chicken before adding them to the flour mixture to which I also added 1/4 tsp. Seasoning salt. I  put the flour mixture in a plastic bag and shook the chicken lightly in the bag; this coats the chicken more evenly and makes less mess than the bowl- then put the bag with the coated chicken in the refrigerator for about 80 minutes). Otherwise, I followed the directions and the flavor was fantastic. Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Now I see why it has gotten five out of five stars from over 500 reviewers. These wings were...dare I say AWESOME! I didn't understand why you had to refrigerate the wings for 60-90 min, until I took them out the fridge and fried them. They get all nice and gummy and form this extra crispy crust when fried. The sauce was neither too hot nor too spicy. I did use unsalted butter and omitted the salt that the recipe called for, but couldn't tell that it was missing due to the sodium of the hot sauce. Again, these were AWESOME, and definitely a  make again in my house!

text:
Wow...Great tasting wings! Like other reviewers, I decided to cut the chicken wings in half and discard the tips.  I made one slight mistake by adding the black pepper and garlic powder to the flour mixture.  I don't think it made a difference.  I love these wings because they stay crispy even after they are coated with the sauce. Other recipes I have tried get soggy once the wings have been coated. I guess it really comes down to personal preference. I didn't have Frank's hot sauce, so I used Louisiana hot sauce from New Orleans.  Yum-O in the words of Rachel Ray. This recipe is a definite keeper!  Thanks, Kelly

text:
Wow!  I took these to a pot luck BBQ, we made them at our house and then transported them hot, they were a huge sucess.  We ended up cooking them twice because I worried about not cooking them for long enough.  The grease didn't need to be changed during the middle which I was afraid it would.  I mixed up the stuff and then left it all in the fridge over night, we cooked them and then some got the hot sauce and some were plain.  Everyone loved it.  I made it using "Rooster Sauce" for the hot sauce, I used 1/2 serving since it's soo spicy.  I highly recommend this for someone who doesn't mind deep frying and wants food that everyone will enjoy.

I guess I'm not saying anything that hasn't already been said... these are delicious, if you cut down on the butter and season up the flour. I added Black pepper, seasoning salt, a bit of Emeril's and a touch of brown sugar. Also doubled the garlic. Was out of Frank's hot sauce, so had to use Tapatio. Hot, hot, HOT! Served with Ranch and celery sticks to cool down the flavor of the hotness a bit. I fried mine, but next time I'll try baking them, just to see the difference.
Thanks so much, Kelly.

Finally, we found the perfect wing sauce recipe. My husband has tried a few times to perfect a sauce but no can do, until we found this recipe. I didn't use wings this time, I used chicken tenders, which I deep fried and put them in the sauce. My son kept asking for more and with football season around the corner, this recipe will be a frequent user. Thanks Kelly!! UPDATE, made wings tonight and baked them @ 375 1hr (drums & wingettes) on racks with jelly roll pans underneath lined with foil. Easy, easy clean up. The guys wanted them hot and twenty four wings didn't last long. No more frying for me, take the chance and bake them!!

"In a small bowl mix together the flour, paprika, cayenne pepper and salt. Place chicken wings in a large nonporous glass dish or bowl and sprinkle flour mixture over them until they are evenly coated. Cover dish or bowl and refrigerate for 60 to 90 minutes."

text:
Mmmm good!  Made this recipe using chicken legs and cooking it on the grill.
First I boiled the chicken legs in water for about 15 mins to cook them through, then I dried them off with paper towels and put the dry ingred. on them.  After an hour in the fridge, I put them on the grill until they were done and put the hot sauce on them in a bowl.
Great flavor!  Will make again.

None
text:
I have tried this recipe twice and the first time, the wings were way to soggy and not quite as hot as we like them. Here are my suggestions...Completely omit the flour mixture. Use more hot sauce ( I prefer Franks) and less butter. Place the wings in the oil and deep fry for 25 minutes. Remove them from the oil and place on a plate covered with paper towels. Then coat them in the hot sauce mixture. The wings came out crispy and spicy (but not uncomfortably spicy).

text:
The sauce in this recipe is excellent.  However, the recipe for the chicken I changed.  I mix 1/4 cup red wine vingar with 1 tsp sugar, 4 1/2 tbl Real Lemon Juice, 1/2 tsp basil.  Used a pastry brush to apply to the chicken then seasoned with McCorm. Chicken.  Bake on 425 for about 45 minutes.  Excellent with the sauce from the recipe.

userID:
9035645
Display Name:
David Byers
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made it a quest to find the best hot wings in the Atlanta area.  Over the past year I have been looking for a hot wing recipe out there.  I have tried several but this one was the best by far.  I have made them twice and my guests were not disappointed.  For me I like them cooked at exactly 11 min and leave the coated wings in the fridge for 90 minutes.  If you do that you will get some GREAT crispy wings.  Also I prefer Texas Pete hot sauce over Tabasco.  Texas Pete is thicker and hangs on the wings better.  To keep grease in check I always remove the chicken from the frying oil and place them on a napkin to drain for a couple of minutes before putting them in the hot sauce mixture.  Then I only leave the wings in the hot sauce mixture for a couple of minutes then remove them  and put them on a plate and serve.  One little secret that I will give you that takes the hot sauce up a notch but don't tell.  Add about 1/4 cup (to taste) of Sriracha Sauce to the hot sauce mixture.  Good luck

text:
Buffalo Wings are not breaded!!!!  These are breaded hot wings.  Correct portion is 3 parts Frank's, to one part butter, with a touch of garlic.    Drain well before coating.  Don't drown the wings, you are only coating them.  And please, don't use Hooter's as your guide.

country:
None
text:
I took the advice of another reviewer and did these in the oven for 50 min @ 350 on a wire rack on a rimmed baking sheet, took them out and sprayed them with olive oil cooking spray.  The spray actually crisped the skin as it was applied.  Back in the oven for 10 minutes @ 375.  I took them out, brushed on the buffalo sauce and back in the oven for 5 minutes.  They were great!  Maybe not as crunchy as if they were fried, but they were crispy.

text:
I am a bit of a wuss so I'll admit I didn't make this recipe for the intent of making them buffalo style wings. But rather I use this recipe for the method of getting super juicy, super flavorful, super crispy wings!!! So that is to say, I follow the exact recipe up until the Buffalo sauce Just because I can't handle heat and just eat it with a milder sauce instead. I believe the key to this recipe is definitely letting the wings sit and dry out in the fridge with the flour dredge on them!! It really does make a world of difference! I've made them up in the morning and let them sit all day and they're just super crispy and juicy and flavorful! I will never use another method ever again!! Definitely worth a try!!!

text:
This recipe deserves all five stars! These were the best "Homemade" wings I have ever had even though I was a little short on the sauce. I followed other reviewers advice and kept them in the fridge the whole 90 minutes. I do recommend rolling each one in the "batter" individually to get a nice through even coating, at first I tried sprinkling it over top like the recipe says but you don't get the entire wing coated. The only change I made was to use minced garlic vs the powder. This one is a keeper.

text:
Made the wings as directed, they came out nice and crispy.  For the sauce I used 1/3 cup franks redhot, 1/3 cup vinegar,  1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cub brown sugar and 3 tbsp molasses, and a bit of cornstarch mixed with cold water to thicken the sauce a bit.  The molasses and sugar cut the hot of the pepper sauce a bit, but leave enough zing to make the saice finger lickin good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
2000+ reviews and 5 stars?  Must be a reason.  So let me tell you the reason.  It's that I never thought I could make fried wings this good.  Lordie.  I put about 1 inch of oil in a 14 inch cast iron skillet and used a heavy, high quality, metal spatter cover for this recipe...next time I might use the dutch oven. I bought 3 dozen wings already so I can freeze em and eventually make a bunch of these wings again--i didn't know the pack i used had only 6 wings. So anyway, these came out fantastic.  Yes the secret seems to be letting them rest and getting the coating a bit gummy before you fry them. After frying, I let them rest on my metal broiler rack/oven sheet combo from my toaster oven. I didn't use the sauce in the recipe, I just slapped on what we had out of the bottle...Frank's, Sweet Baby Ray's, and Tropical Pepper co. habanero/mango/coconut sauce.  They were not the least bit oily or greasy.  Fried doesn't have to equal bad, but badly fried food, now that is in fact, bad.  I'd love to make these regularly.

text:
These aren't "authentic" Buffalo wings. Nonetheless, they are fabulous! Made these last year for the Super Bowl, and will be making them again this year. I made them exactly as the recipe states, to a T. The only thing I will change from here forward is cut back on the butter in the sauce. I would make the sauce-to-butter ratio 1/2 cup hot sauce to 1/3 cup butter. Use Frank's Red Hot for the sauce and you'll have the perfect wings.

text:
These wings came out perfect and I made several batches over two days leading up to the Superbowl for hungry teenagers.  I purchased high quality bare wings at the butcher and followed the recipe exactly. After taking out from the refrigerator after the 90 minutes, I tossed them around in the flour to recoat. I fried them for 12 minutes in oil at 375 degrees.  Then placed them in a deep dish and tossed with the sauce that was still very warm. 
Also, some that I made the day before, I reheated in the oven for a half hour at 350 degrees and they were great.

text:
Wonderful hot wings! I made them with Mexican hot sauce, which was all I had, and added a bit of brown sugar for that "sweet and spicy" effect. Perfect! I left them in the refrigerator the full 90 minutes and they were so crispy even after adding the sauce. I did not soak them in the sauce, just drizzled enough to coat, and put the remaining sauce in a side serving dish for whom ever wanted more. Also, I did not have wings so I used drumsticks and they were still awesome. You really can't improve on perfect. This one is going in my recipe box for sure.

I just made these tonight and they are deeee-lish!!! I get so tired of hearing about so-called authentic buffalo wings. Authentic isn't necessarily the best. I've prepared and eaten wings just about every way imaginable and these are by far the best wings I've ever had. If you want them hotter just kick the sauce up a notch and you're good to go! I think the key to any good wing is the quality of the wing itself. Has to be plump and meaty. Great, simple recipe!! It's my new go-to. -Arnie1

text:
As written, this recipe is awesome.  Although I do not care for hot wing sauce, I just used my favorite BBQ sauce instead.  I have tried both frying them and baking.  Obviously, frying is going to give a crispier texture that you expect from wings.  Baking them works, but is not even close.  I tried the whole spraying them with cooking spray, putting them on a rack up off the baking sheet, and they were just, meh.  If you're contemplating frying vs. baking, follow the recipe, and fry them!

text:
I made these wings in an infrared convection oven (60 minutes at 375 degrees F.) and they were sublime. I sprayed them with cooking spray, and then drizzled the barest amount of canola oil over them to get that crunchy goodness. I turned them over half way during cooking time. Wonderful recipe, thank you!

text:
My husband loves these wings and doesn't want me to buy store brand or restaurant wings again.  I add a little bit more cayenne and garlic powder to the flour mixture and after refrigerating and before they go into the oven or fryer I coat them again in the leftover flour.  This makes them SO crispy.  My nieces and nephews (7-13) loved these too (with Ranch).  It's a great copy cat recipe!

text:
Excellent!  I used smoked paprika in the breading, which gave a great flavor.  I also used about a 4:1 ratio of Frank's Red Hot to butter, since I like my wings hot!  They were perfectly spicy!  I baked them ~55 min at 375, turning halfway through.  Since I had breaded them while they were still frozen, they didn't crisp up, but they still tasted great.

text:
These were by far the best I've had!  I made a double batch, flouring them in a plastic baggie for 80 minutes.  Then sprayed with oil, baked at 375 for 25 minutes, flip chicken and pans, bake another 25 minutes, then drizzle with some hot sauce and broil for 3 minutes.  Turned out moist on inside, crunchy on outside.  Tossed with sauce.  Regretfully they went straight hot from oven and covered in sauce into a tupperware for the car ride to superbowl party so they got a little mushy from the steam.  But still the best!!  So many great compliments.  Thanks a bunch for the recipe!!  WHO DAT SAY DEY GONNA BEAT DEM SAINTS!

text:
I'd give this one 6 stars if I could.  Thanks so much for the suggestion of baking them.  I added a bit extra cayenne pepper to the flour, along with some onion powder and garlic powder for more flavour.  When they were finished baking I thought they looked like they weren't crispy enough so I broiled them for a couple of minutes -and that made all the difference.  They came out beyond my expectations and none of us missed the deep-frying at all!  Next time, when they're finished baking, I'm going to put them on the George Foreman grill for a couple of minutes to see if they grill up nicely.

text:
I am not a fan of chicken wings, but I enjoyed everything from the coating to the sauce! The key is allowing the wings to rest with the flour on them for a minimum of an hour. I took the wings out of the fridge about 15 minutes prior to frying so the wings would not bring down the temperature of the oil too much. These are the perfect snack to serve during football season! I will definitely make these again!

Yumm-o!! These were so good. We followed the recipe as it reads. We did fry them and they turned out perfect, not greasy at all.Having the wings rest in the fridge is important! When we made the sauce we cut back on the butter(we actually used margarine)and used more hot sauce(Franks Red Hot)also added a couple of big shots of Tabasco b/c we like em a little hotter, and  what can I say these were right on! We will be making this our new and only HOT WINGS recipe. Also, we like variety so we made teriyaki wings and these were good too. I don't care what kind of sauce you use this is how wings should be. Thanks for sharing!!! PS. I have never eaten the wings at this restaurant and now I don't have too!

text:
I love this recipe!!  We like really hot wings so we cut the ratio of butter to hot sauce 1 to 4.  I use Frank's Hot Sauce.  Also, I use the Chicken  Fried Chicken recipe on AllRecipes submitted by CASSJW for the breading.  It stays on the chicken the best.  After reading over reviews, I do the flour, egg, then breading technique for coating the chicken.

Goodness these were soooo good and they did in fact taste just like they're from a restaurant, but they are so bad for you.  My advice for those that are hesitant to make these because of the frying is to bake them or grill them instead.  They're good either way with the base of this recipe.  No changes needed; this recipe was good as is.  This is a great party pleaser, but my husband and I shared them between the two of us with onion rings and celery with ranch dressing.  So good!

text:
baked at 375 degrees for 20min on each side. poured on 1/2 the sauce for 5min each side. not sure if the butter is necessary since after i was done baking, all the melted butter collected on one side of the pan. i think next time i'll try to play around and omit it all together or just use olive oil. def tailor to your own taste. my hot sauce was too spicy for MIL to eat and i ended up adding some honey to cut down on the heat. overall a great recipe for buffalo wings!

text:
I do the flour-coating thing in a zip-lock bag -- much easier.   And I absolutely LOVE SPICY SPICY SPICY!  But it's too much work, and to messy trying to get an ounce of meat off a wing.  Use drumsticks instead.  It's much more rewarding.  My fryer only cooks four at a time, so I put the finished ones in my 200 degree oven (which crisps it up nicely, I might add) until the rest of the drumsticks are done.  Thank you for the recipe.  I'll never order chicken wings at my local bar again.  Now I can make them better.

text:
Okay, this is my first review ever on this website, have used recipes from here times before, but this was the first one I would say I HAD to write a review.  I am a chicken wing fanatic, I never made them homemade before, but have eaten from every restaurant imaginable.  I can say without a doubt these are the best tasting wings I have ever had.  I made them last night in honor of March Madness to just snack on.  I purchased pre-made wings & drumettes, so the pre-made ones could be ready when my husband got home, and let the recipe wingetts set in the flour in the fridge, and he preferred the recipe ones over the pre-made ones.  My 6 & 7 year old boys couldn't get enough, even took some outside to their friends.  The store brought ones, just sat there lonely.  I had to eat those, since these were all gone.  My husband just called and said I have to make more tonight.  Didn't change the recipe at all, followed recipe to a T, and came out perfect!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this twice now and everyone loves it.  I used a combo of chicken wings and chicken breast strips and baked it like other reviewers suggested.  The only modifications that I made was add garlic powder and black pepper to the flour mixture and used an entire bottle of buffalo hot sauce to one stick of butter and threw in a few dashes of tobasco sauce.  I also let my chicken sit a lot longer than the recipe says.  I got up early and coated the chicken and left it in the fridge for several hours it seemed to make the coating stick really well and made them very crispy in the oven.  Thanks for the recipe, this was a big hit at our super bowl party.

LUCYRICARDO

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/177308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had never made buffalo wings before and spent a lot of time reading others reviews on here before I made these!  They were AWESOME! Tasted totally like Chili's or any other place like that. I did let them sit for a couple hours with the flour coating on them before I made them. I was torn about frying vs. baking but I decided to go ahead and use canola oil and fry them. At first, I didn't have the oil hot enough but quickly realized this and they did end up taking an hour but was worth it.  The only thing I would say is the sauce is more "buttery" and it's not flaming hot like some people like. I would use less butter and then more hot sauce. I used Franks Hot Buffalo Wing flavored.  I really didn't think they would turn out so good but our guests said they taste exactly like you would eat in a restaurant so I suppose that is why they are called "Restaurant-Style" wings!

text:
This is a fabulous recipe.  Best wings I've had anywhere . . . . I love the way you can play with the sauce - Chipotle Tobasco - Szechuan - Frank's - yumm! One secret - I add a bit of Mott's Caesar Seasoned salt to the flour - it gives it a nice tang.  It's very important to let them sit in the fridge with the flour - don't try to cut the time short.

text:
These are great!  I made them for New Years and everyone loved them.  One of my friends said they were the best wings she had ever had.  I decided to bake mine, as some others did.  I prepared them the same and just put them on a baking sheet with some oil to coat the bottom of the pan.  The key with baking them is not to turn them or adjust them at all while baking.  The breading will come off unless they are completely done.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is the best chicken wing recipe I have ever used. Didn't change anything seasoning wise. I always let my chicken wings set in a equal parts solution of cider vinegar and water prior to flouring. I then place them in a big plastic bag to ensure that the flour mixture will coat each individual wing. Must be in fridge for 90 min prior to cooking for best results. I use shortening when cooking these because they did not come out as good with regular vegetable oil. Yummmm....

This recipe may seem like a lot of work, but it's actually really easy so don't be intimidated! 
I used a ziplock bag instead of a bowl because it is much easier to get them coated evenly. 
Remember to use a good hot sauce, i find tobasco too chili, I prefer a milder hot sauce...I salted my hot sauce mixture too to give it more taste
YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED WITH THIS GREAT RECIPE!

text:
I was really expecting something out of this world as per the hundreds of five star reviews, but we were pretty disappointed as these were just 'nice' but not spectacular. It amounts to fried chicken with a spicy sauce, but it did not taste like the famous ones at all. I followed the recipe exactly so I'm not sure why this is so, except that perhaps using the ''Frank's Hot Sauce'' makes all the difference in the world, in which case it should be listed in the original recipe. As two other reviewers noted, however, this recipe is *not* what buffalo wings are, so the name is misleading. They were pretty good but not worthy of five stars, sorry.

text:
We live in WNY and know Buffalo style chicken wings.  Although this is not exactly the same as you would get from a restaurant around here, it is the closest we have ever achieved making them at home!  After making the sauce, we let it settle and 'clarified' the butter.  This allowed the sauce to be a little thicker.  Coating the wings with flour helps them to be crispier.  We will use the recipe again.  THANK YOU!

text:
Made these using skinless, boneless, chicken breasts. Cut them into 'chicken fingers'. The flour mix was great..did add garlic powder and more cayenne. I no longer own a deep fryer so did fry them in my wok using canola oil , about 4 min a side. They came out crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I used 1 cup of my favorite new HOT SAUCE..'Valentina' made in Mexico and it is Hotttt! and has a great flavour as well. I think this will be my new wingless 'Hot Wings' recipe from now on. Less fat - more flavour. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This recipe is definitely a hit- I used it on in a buffalo chicken wrap sandwich that my bf loved! However I made one change to the recipe- my mother has the "original" buffalo wing recipe (clipped from a 1980 magazine & saved) which recommends adding a small amount of white vinegar to the hot sauce/butter mix. For this recipe, I used about a tsp. It adds a little extra zing to the hot sauce mix.

country:
None
text:
This sounds alot like the way I have made wings for years..the only difference I make is that I add a little corn syrup or pancake syrup to break up the hot sauce a little..for hot I use 2 parts Franks hot sauce to butter, medium 1/2 hot sauce and 1/2 butter, mild, 1/2 part hot sauce to 1 part butter. I melt the butter with fresh garlic only until the butter it is barely melted. I then take it off the heat and whisk in the hot sauce so it gets thick. You may also use Frank's Wing Sauce in a pinch...

Awesome! I use this recipe all the time! We are huge wing fans and I was looking for some way to make them a little healthier. These are really great baked. I took a suggestion from this site and spray the wings with a little pam and turn up the heat for the last few minutes of baking. A huge hit everytime! I usually leave out the spice and use a honey mustard dipping sauce (from this site) for the kids. They love it!

text:
This is a great recipe!  It has a little heat but isn't overly hot--just perfect for our family.  If you like a real spicy chicken wing, add more hot sauce.  We modified it a little so that we could make buffalo chicken sandwiches.  I cut the chicken into approx 1-1 1/2 inch slices (which only require 6-8 minutes in the deep frier at 375).  My husband raved over it so many times, I will be making this again soon.

text:
These wings are fabulous. This is the best wing recipe I've ever tried.  I made a few changes to make the wings very hot.  The flour/pepper combination is great, but I added a bit more cayenne pepper. I also used about a cup of Frank's hot sauce, 4 tablespoons of butter, and a splash of white vinegar.  Finally, I baked the wings in a 300 degree oven for about five minutes to dry them out.

text:
Harden is correct about not breading the wings, but you do not have to use Franks Red hot. Ive made my own that I will put up against Franks or any other commercial sauce. Also a good tip to get them nice and crispy is to fry them for about 5 to 7 minutes and as soon as the oil temp drops a bit, pull them and allow the oil to reach 400 again and then drop them in for the last 7 minutes and you will get perfect wings that are crispy on the outside and juicy in the middle.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the instructions regarding the ingredients, exactly as listed. I have made this many times using this recipe now. Depending on the amount of time I have I prepare it different. If I have enough time, I will coat the wings with the flour mixture the morning I plan on making them. At dinner time, I bake the wings (in a baking ceramic pan with a thin layer of butter on the bottom) withOUT the sauce. I set my oven for 350 degrees and after 20 minutes, I turn them over and sprinkle any extra flour mixture I have. I leave them for another 20 minutes. Then I take them out and coat them with the sauce at 375 degrees and 10 additional minutes (we like them crispier). My husband loves them!

freeholdnjusa

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7195006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve been making my own wings for years and I can say these are the best I’ve ever made.  I didn’t fry because I made 20 wings (40 pieces) and it would of taken longer to fry a few batches.  Placed racks on a broiler pan, sprayed chicken lightly with Pam, baked 20 minutes at 400 degrees, flipped and sprayed with Pam again and baked another 20 minutes at 400. I made my sauce using Frank’s Red Hot WINGS because the instructions said just Hot Sauce and  I thought Tabasco sauce would be watery. Since I made more than double the wings I doubled the coating mix and the sauce recipes which was the perfect amount. Next time I might fry if I don’t have a big batch to make and that will be very soon because I’m putting this into my dinner rotation.  DELICIOUS!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were really good. I used 8 large frozen wings from Sams. I put the flower mixture on them while they thawed in a bag and also in warm water for part of the time. Because of the frozen water, it turned to a paste so I have no idea if that was bad or good. It sat for about 45-50 minutes in and out of the warm water. The sauce was good and I added a little bit of coconut sugar because we like the sweet taste and that was good but I would add more next time. We used a deep fryer and fried them for about 5 minutes. The batter did stick to the basket though. It was set to 400 which I think was the highest setting. I'm excited to make these again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect chicken! I haven't made the sauce yet. I used the same seasonings in approximate proportions - I just eye balled it to my taste. I did not refrigerate. after defrosting chicken,  I soaked in buttermilk for approximately 15 minutes. Then poured buttermilk off. I left some buttermilk hanging on to chicken and I seasoned the chicken before flouring. Then I tossed the chicken together. The remaining buttermilk made it like a sauce. I dipped dripping sauced wings in flour, coated, set aside, seasoned floured wings, then tossed again and then fried at 375.

text:
First off great recipe. Things to remember, make sure you cook with peanut oil. I use seasoned flour and a sifter to get a nice light coat on. Also add a little bit of onion powder to the sauce. Never completely cover the wings in sauce as they can become soggy. Use a ladle to drizzle sauce on.

text:
First off, I'm not "from Buffalo" and have never been, but anyone rating 1 star because of a word needs to get off their high horse and actually make a recipe before rating it (because we all know you didn't actually even try the recipe).
This recipe is DELICIOUS. My husband loves wings and he says these are the best he has ever tasted! I literally make them every week and it is definitely a must to let them sit in the fridge for an hour before frying or they won't be crispy. The only thing I've changed over time is only using half the amount of butter in the sauce because we like it hot.

text:
I've made these twice now and LOVE THEM! MashaAllah! I use freshly ground whole einkorn flour instead to give it a bit of sweetness. And I double the spices for the coating.  I don't deep fry, but if I do I will use coconut oil instead of veg. oil. I bake them on 220°C and turn after 20 minutes. The last  10 minutes I put the broiler on to crisp them. Inshaallah
I always make a double batch and freeze the extra to snack on later.  Just heat them up, or even pull them out of the freezer and just let them thaw, sometimes they don't even make it to the oven. ;) My husband loves to nibble on them throughout the afternoon. MashaAllah! A great staple for any fridge!  Great main meal, Great snack!!!!! MashaAllah!
I also make my own hot sauce with fresh tomatoes and chilis. Wonderful eats!!!!!!

text:
very very good.  I did one additional thing that I do with my honey teryaki chicken nuggets.  I leave the sauce in the sauce pan on the stove on low.  As the wings are fried, I put them in the sauce pan for a minute, then take them out, place them on a rack that's in a cookie sheet (line with foil to catch the drip) and bake them at 250 for about 5-10 minutes.  The wings absorb the flavor and kicks it up another notch.

text:
These wings are perfection. We made then last night and every single Wing was eaten. We were a little concerned about using the flour mixture as we don't like breaded wings. I do agree that you must do the flour mixture to make them crispy and the sauce sticks to the wings. We put the flour mixture on the wings early in the morning and cooked later in the evening and they were perfect. We cook our wings using the two step fry 1st we cook the wings at 275 for 15 minutes to light golden brown. We then turn the heat to 375 to crisp the outside. We like crispy wings so we cook them for 15 minutes. These wings are just like restaurant style and we will use the method from now on.

Here's a Nother way to do this recipe. Mix all the dry ingredients except for the flower in the sauce pan when you're melting the hot sauce and butter and let that simmer for a little bit. If you buy a bag of already cooked and coated chicken wings, the non-buffalo style. Keep them up in the oven and then once the chicken is done in a large bowl put the chicken wings in with the sauce mixed together and then serve. It's really good and it's just like you get that the 99 restaurant

text:
YUMMY!! I followed Anydolls variation as it cuts down on fat. I also doubled the spices putting 1/2 directly on chicken and 1/2 in flour mixture for dredging. I would double that. Also turn chicken over 1/2 through baking. Spraying with cooking oil GREAT. Since the dipping sauce is so fatty cooking chicken on a rack a draining off was a wonderful idea. Chicken crisp and good. If wings are meaty you will need to bake the 'drummets' about 10 minutes longer than the less meaty parts. Will make again soon!!

text:
I made this tonight.  I made just a few changes.  First of all, I used a clove of fresh garlic, minced, in the sauce instead of garlic powder.  Also, since I was making this for our grandsons I cut the cayenne pepper in half.  I used garlic salt in place of the garlic powder and salt in the flour coating.  Oh, and I used Bob's Red Mil 1 to 1 gluten free flour instead of regular all purpose flour as we are all gluten free.   I cooked the drum part of the wings for 15 minutes and the smaller wing end for 10.  Everyone loved these wings.

amyhinz1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time i made them i thought these were great! However, im about to share a little secret that will ensure the crispiest and best wings youll ever have! So here it is.. first of all you want to lightly flour each wing and i mean lightly, second, you want to fry your wings low and slow like a med/low setting, do this for 15 mins. Remove wings from hot oil and let tjem drain on a rack or paper towel if you do not have a wire rack. Your wings will be cooked through at this point but not ready to eat, and here is the most important part, transfer wings to a baking sheet and pop in the freezer for a few hrs uncovered. ( very important.) Take the wings out 15 mins before yoir ready to fry them for the second time. Heat your oil to med high and fry wings for 10 more mins, flipping every few mins if you dont have a deep fryer. Then drain them amd toss the hot crispy wings in your favorite sauce! There is a science to why these are cooked this way.. whateber it is, these are the best wings ive ever had!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have deep fried maybe 6 times in 16 years. This was one of those times and it was worth it.  I used a small pot (maybe 20oz of veggie oil) and could only do 3-4 wingettes at a time. I fried  small batches @ 375 F for 9-10 minutes.  Cooled wingettes on a cookie rack to drain. Made Tabasco sauce per recipe, tossing wingettes  in pot in small batches. Laid out on baking sheet and put in pre-heated oven at 325 degrees for 15 additional minutes. I served these wings plus teriyaki wingettes, butter/rosemary wingettes , and plain fried for pre-4th of July. My fussiest eater can't wait for next time. The buffalo wings went first before the teriyaki. This recipe is on my summer hit parade surpassing jerk wings.

text:
I made these and they were delicious. While it was spicy I added more paprika and cayenne for a bit more heat. I also changed up the butter/hot sauce ratio as per another persons comments. I used about 110gm butter with a bottle (300ml) of Franks hot sauce. I also cut the full wings up into three pieces and only used the two main parts. I used about 1-1/12 kg of wings and there was enough sauce and flour for this. I deep fried mine, the skin was crispy and the chicken was juicy. Enjoy !!

text:
Absolutely loved these! I followed the recipe precisely, till the bbq sauce. I had no hot sauce. I used ketchup, lemon juice, red wine vinegar, cayane pepper, honey and brown sugar, and butter. I heated that up and put on the side. After frying the wings, I dipped lightly into the sauce, and fried again for a minute or two. After laying fried wings on paper towel I drizzled sauce on top in a bowl. When all wings were in the bowl I mixed them up to cover all wings. HUGE hit for the super bowl !

country:
None
text:
These wings are bar none, some of the best ever! I have tried all kinds of wings recipes, and this is one of my favorites... There are wing eaters in my household that prefer their wings dry (rather than the directed wet) style, so after frying the wings for 5 minutes on each side, I placed them on a wire rack on a foil lined pan in a 400 degree oven for another 10 minutes. The wings turned out crispy, tasty, and perfect! I used Frank's, which wasn't spicy enough for my taste, so I will be making these again and experimenting with some other hot sauces! Thanks for such a great dish!

I dont like fried food so I did as another person did

They tasted just likr fried wing, but better!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Too much butter, as other's have mentioned. I add a couple of small chunks of butter and throw in some Franks, add a tiny dash of vinegar, some garlic powder, cayenne, chilli powder or Tobasco sauce, Worcestershire sauce. If taste is too buttery, add more Franks to taste. I don't add any salt or pepper. The sauce is ok! 

SOMETIMES I mix in a little Thai Sriracha sauce with the Franks and it seems to taste more like the restaurant version...I don't know...give it a try though.

country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out great. Since I had to triple the recipe, I poured the sauce over the done wings and put them in the oven with the oven turned on 350 degrees Fahrenheit. I kept doing that every time a batch got done and it was amazing. If you let the chicken sit in the oven if you have multiple batches, the wings won't get soggy. They stay crunchy! This is just a tip if you have multiple batches or if you are waiting for somebody to come home to start eating!

But I was not crazy about the dredge or flouring recipe. I think it needed way more spices and salt, especially if one might eat these without the sauce.  I don't know...I really just don't like wings!! Boyfriend liked so I gave it 4 stars.

text:
Wings were delicious.  My only change was to season the wings after drying them and before adding the flour, and adding powder garlic, onion and black pepper  to the flour.I also only placed it the fridge uncovered for half an hour.  Super crispy, will make again.  Thanks for the recipe.
Edit: 2/4/18: made them again, didn't bother drying them, just drenched in flour mixture Andrea they were super crispy. Added extra salt, cayenne to flour. Added cayenne and some habanero sauce to hot sauce.

I am a wing addict and I am veeeery picky about them too. This recipe is God send! I made these for the Super Bowl and had to call family over on Monday just so I could make more. That's how AMAZING these wings are. If you like crunchy, juicy, perfectly seasoned wings this is your recipe. BTW the last 3 wings of the humongous batch I made on Sunday sat covered in sauce for over one hour and they were still crunchy when I finally killed them.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent wings! I had never attempted making wings but saw a $2.99 bag (20 wings)when shopping and I figured why not? I searched google and found this recipe. I followed the directions as stated with two exceptions. First, I like my wings hot so I used more hot sauce than stated and I used Franks regular not the buffalo wing sauce. Second, since I live in sunny Arizona I used my gas grill. I had some left over aluminum foil pans (%0.99) and spread them out and cooked at about 450 degrees for 35 minutes and flipped them over once midway through. I highly recommend this recipe. My son and I ate for under 5 dollars. I will be making them again in 2 weeks for my super bowl party.

Made these for a super bowl party, and they were a huge hit. Allowing the flour mixture to get tacky was a great idea. It made the outer coating so light and crunchy when fried. They even stayed crisp after being coverd in the wing sauce. This a real keeper.

userID:
4135052
Display Name:
Suzy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe today, one day after the Super Bowl because we had too many other dishes, I just didn't get to it before game time. I ended up buying drumsticks because the grocery store was all out of fresh wings.  So my floured drumsticks sat in the fridge overnight! About 20 hours to be exact before I cooked them for lunch the next day.  They turned out DELICIOUS!!! When I put them in the bag of flour mix, there was a lot of leftover flour on the bottom of the bag (I had doubled the flour mix due to the size of the drum sticks), but by the time I took them out to fry them up the next day, most of the flour had been absorbed into the chicken. These were unbelievably crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside!!!  The drumsticks worked out GREAT! Better than wings because my sons are only 5 and 6 and prefer more meat and less "weird stuff" along with the meat. For the kids I just lightly salted the fried chicken and it was amazing!! They ate a few  pieces each!  For the adults, I followed the sauce recipe except doubled it ( bigger chicken) and added about an 1/8th of a cup of habanero pepper sauce in addition to the cayenne pepper sauce.  I used Frank's hot sauce as that is what I had on hand and really like for wings.  There were nice and hot with the Habanero addition.  Thanks so much for sharing this wonderful recipe and to all of you who put in your 2 cents worth. I will definitely be making this dish again real soon!! And with actual chicken wings next time!!!

If I could give this more than 5 stars, I would! The basic coating and setup (refrigerate for 60-90 mins) is spot on. Thereafter you can cook how you wish, fry or bake; hot sauce or BBQ.  I baked mine and added BBQ on half of them and cooked 5 more minutes. As for the hot wings, I heated up Frank's wing sauce and dipped them into the saucepan and moved them right to the platter. text:
All I can say is "Awesome". This recipe is great. I made these for the Superbowl today and they rocked! I followed the recipe with the only change being to use more Frank's hot sauce. However, I used a large Tupperware container and I apparently had just enough sauce to coat the inside of the container and not much on the wings. I used a basting brush to get the sauce from the container onto the wings. Luckily I was the only one eating these so it worked out OK. Next time I will just make more sauce. One thing I really liked was the crunchy coating after deep frying. These were the best chicken wings I have ever eaten.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought these were pretty good.  I made mine using boneless chicken breasts cut into strips, in order to add them to a salad.  I did bake them as others suggested, because I have a real problem with frying them in oil.  Not because of health reasons, but because I never seem to do them right.  Either I burn them or they are undercooked, so I try to steer clear.  They turned out a little dry in the oven, moreso than I hoped, but that's probably my fault too as opposed to that of the recipe, since others baked them without problems.  Either I cut my strips too thin or did something wrong with the baking.  I thought the sauce was fantastic.  I used Frank's, and made a little bit more than was called for because I was using a tad more chicken.  The flavor was great, they had a good crunch to them, the perfect amount of spice.  They were sloppier than I wanted for my salad, but seeing as how it's SUPPOSE to be that way, I should've expected it!  I stuck them in the fridge for about 10 minutes hoping that it would keep it from gooping on the salad, but it didn't work.  Still, great taste and a fantastic dinner!

If you want to make them sweet and tangy (and not hot) just leave out the hot sauce and hot pepper in the sauce and add an equal amount of regular (like Kraft Original) BBQ sauce as butter and THOROUGHLY mix together with butter/garlic powder mixture. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this the flour and chicken made a horridly sticky mess in the bowl so I foiled & sprayed a casserole dish, used a plastic bag to put the flour mix in and dropped the chicken strips (I used chicken breasts about 4 of them cut into strips) one at a time into to make sure they were coated and lined them up in the dish, covered it overnight and took them out to bake them (someone had suggested that, but they didn't turn out crispy...I will try to fry next time). This helped reduce the amount of clean up in the kitchen. I also kicked the spice up some by adding some crushed red pepper and a small amount of crushed habreno into the flour mix and into the sauce itself. It brought enough heat to please my dad (the buffalo wing critic) and my boyfriend. Thanks for the recipe!

I have made this MANY times! I only use the hot sauce & butter & garlic. We find that plenty spicy enough. I also add some sugar to help tone down some of the spice ( for my boys). Always use Louisianna hot sauce.
I dont have a fryer so I just bake the wings, get them crispy, add the sauce & bake some more.
I always serve them with frozen french fries...we like our "saucy fries"!
